Jones - Nah, this story isn't over, just wait until he hits prison.  Inmates typically have a whole different set of punishments for what they view as worst offenders.  Rapists, Child molesters, and wife beaters.  Depending on where he goes, he can probably expect to have all of his shit stolen daily/weekly (whenever he gets any mail), likely physical assault, possibly sexual assault, and then whatever the inmates feel like doing to him, just to make things worse.  A <redacted> spent some time in jail, <redacted> would tell me all these stories of what it was like there.  One thing inmates would do is take a dump in your shoes, and then use a plastic bag to push it up into the toe area, so you couldn't see it before putting your shoes on.   That's just one example.  So yeah, Mr. Jones is about to spend the worst possible time you can possibly spend, in jail.  Virginia - I think right now, at this time in American history, we can all agree that political rhetoric/venom, has ratcheted up, and yes, higher than it was during Obama's presidency (This does not mean, that Obama was always treated with respect...that's an utter fallacy, it just means it's getting worse), and I have to say, this act, and the stabbing, etc... are a natural escalation of the rhetoric (At least, I've expected it to go this route for awhile now).  You may think no sane person would go there, but, not everyone is sane.   There are truly those out there who think that just by killing all political opponents, it will solve some problems.  And with the rhetoric getting worse and worse and worse, I don't think it's any surprise that it starts translating into real world violence.  And, until we do start acting like adults, and behaving in a manner befitting the ideals/principles of our Democracy, this will continue to get worse, and we will continue to see more people justifying violence towards political opposites.  Grenfell Tower - I don't really have words for this one...  The footage of that guy really hit me hard.  I hope the best for all the survivors, their families, the responder's, friends and anyone else affected. Utter tragedy.

While I firmly believe the pedophilia is wrong, especially when it harms children, I do believe that we as a society need to make it more easy to get help for it. It is a psychological problem, and some states even allow for psychiatrists to report and get people put in jail just for admitting that they have had thoughts about children, there seems to be no way for people to get proper help for it, due to the fact that everyone around them will hate them as soon as they find out. It seems to be quite backwards to hate something without trying to fix it. Everyone seems to be perfectly fine and feel so self righteous when they talk about how disgusting pedophiles are,even if they didn't do anything wrong. All it does is push these people further and further away,until they feel like they have no escape but the actually commit a crime.      Don't get me wrong though, as soon as they touch a child or anything of the sort, they need to be punished to the fullest extend of the law. These people often were abused children themselves, and need the proper psychological help.
Open conversation is fine and all, but kids and pedophilia is a goddamned red line in the sand if there ever was one. There is no discussion about it. None

One thing I feel like you and a lot of other people don't realize is that Pedophilia isn't really a choice. Child molestation is a choice, soliciting sexual acts from children is a choice, but having the urges isn't. The more we treat the word pedophile as the same as child molester, the more pedophiles who are morally upright don't feel comfortable getting the help they need. And if they don't get the help they need, it's that much more likely the urges make them go crazy and they go over the line.   Child molestation is wrong and disgusting. What this youtuber did was wrong and disgusting. But pedophilia is a mental condition and people with it need help, both for themselves and for the sake of those they might hurt. I usually agree with you, but the stance you take on this subject and the way you treat the terms pedophile and child molester as synonymous is something that does more harm than good.

I work on fire alarms all the time. The 12 month testing is an annual inspection. While doing these inspection It requires setting off the system and making a bunch of noise. you have no idea how many people ignore the alarm and just continue to do what they are doing. I was doing a school and in the middle of the building there was a teacher setting up decorations for her class. She had no idea why it the fire alarm was active, she just ignored it. I also worked on a hotel that where the back half of the building burnt down because the front desk silenced it, assuming it was a false alarm. Luckily the back wasn't occupied so nobody got hurt, but fire alarms are the main reason why people safely get out of building. Don't ignore them.

You're Right. Pedophilia is wrong Phil. That's obvious, but this is no different than any other illness. These people are tacitly perturbed and well, I get it. It shouldn't be normalized but there has to be better acknowledgment other than " they are sick, blast them all off to the moon " or " Insert same vein thought."  Again, it's tacit that were all frustrated and disgusted so why not? Why not take that anger and put it into something constructive rather than speaking "the resounding obvious." There needs to be some sort of acceptance to the illness even if I and you, don't like it.  Because its never going anywhere, there is no cure, we don't need to like it or accept it, just need to view it differently.  What I purpose is better conversations the kind that recognizes the illness and looks into better ways to treat these people rather than just hating them or marginalizing them as garbage people. I don't sympathize and nor do I think it should be normalized, but I am thinking differently on this topic.  I could be wrong, but I tend to think to lock them all up or "insert action" on these people isn't a viable answer that works.  There has to sadly be some acceptance somewhere.  Hope this finds you well and again, perhaps I'm wrong, but sometimes you need to be wrong to try and see from different angels.

If your point is to give a word of caution to other young girls then there's really no reason to include your own surprise at their actions and how you'd act so much better in this situation; but whatever, I'm not seeing anything fundamentally wrong with the original post and my point isn't to go after Ivy.  What I'm appalled at is the amount of presumably grown up people in the comment section giving responses such as "Oh but you ARE smarter than them, sweetie" and "I used to be smarter/more intelligent than other girls my age too!". Seriously? How do you think victims of this pedophile are going to feel when they read your comments? That they're not "as smart" or "as intelligent" as some other girls their age? And that this is why they're victimized? It's fine to call for others to try and stay safe, it's fine to call for more education on the subject, but it's NOT fine to sit in a comment section and have a god damn circle jerk around how much "smarter" you were than other girls when you were a teenager and exclaim shit like oh "FINALLY someone with common sense". If anyone of his victims is reading this, please listen: You being victimized has NOTHING to do with how smart or intelligent you are. The amount of education or information you have on a single subject has absolutely nothing to do with your ability to process that information. And no, just because you might've been told "Don't trust strangers on the internet", that does not make you "informed" on the topic and there is absolutely NO REASON you are to blame for being victimized by this this guy.   And to the rest of you, what the actual fuck? "Oh if only more girls were as smart then less girls could be taken advantage of." NO, just fucking NO. If less guys would act like fucking MONSTERS like this one, then less girls would be taken advantage of. That's not to say that girls or women can't take measures to stay safe, and of course it's important that we give that education to young women to guard them best we can, but don't twist the fkin rhetoric here into being about how girls could do better to prevent getting fucked over by men when what we should focus on is why so many men do these things and how to prevent that in the future. +NaCl3 Yup, pretty sure North Koreans don't have access to the Internet at all :P We kind of speak almost the same language, but their Korean is different enough to confuse us when we hear it haha

+NaCl3 I think the select few you're talking about are the ones that are higher up in the ladder of the government. They don't allow access to the Internet for the public for the same reason why China has banned Facebook. They're afraid their people might find out too much  and realise that their propaganda is BS.  If I saw anyone claiming to be commenting from North Korea in comment sections I'd either think they're lying or I'd be very worried :D

+NaCl3 Their propaganda is quite effective, and it's not that overplayed by the media. What they basically tell their people is that the "Western world" (eg America) is a source of all evil and is out to get them. Add military power and media manipulation to this, and boom, complete, utter dictatorship. Trump kind of made it worse by firing threats at them, practically confirming their propaganda to the North Korean public, who obviously would have no way of knowing if what their government is telling them is true. All they're told is that this president of America is degrading their leader and saying America can wipe out North Korea if it wanted to. That's why many presidents in the past (including South Korean) have tried to be friendly with North Korea - they wanted to change the skewed view the North Koreans have on the "outside world". Their home country is all they've ever known. There are a lucky few who manage to escape to China or South Korea (one guy made it to the news) but this is a huge risk - they're leaving their families behind to be killed for betraying their country, they can get shot on the spot, etc. And they don't get nice looks from others either - some South Koreans are suspicious of them since they could easily be spies who "escaped".  The majority of the North Korean public love their dictator. We'd think that they would hate him but nah. To them, he's the only condom that's providing protection against the "outside world" from screwing them over. Quite sad. And hella scary.

+NaCl3 Sorry for the long comment above, haha, many people don't know much about North Korea (or care until it makes it to their media outlet) so I wanted to explain a little. Also, aw, thanks! English isn't my first language so I'm always very surprised when some native speakers I know can't tell the difference between their and there, or the difference between its and it's. Maybe they get so used to speaking it rather than caring about the nitty gritty bits?

+NaCl3 Indeed, I didn't like the two options you guys were stuck with either. It's unfortunate you guys had to pick between a rotten apple and a rotten orange. I would have voted for Sanders, he seems to actually care about the people. But in this world it's only the loud ones that get the most attention, which is also why North Korea could get away with so much crap without anyone really noticing. It's even worse that they're not exactly in bad conditions either - imagine South Korea but a lot cheaper, that's what North Korea looks like. If you were born there, you would probably think there was nothing wrong with your country. If you ever felt suspicion against your leader's decisions, you'd first question your sanity rather than your society. Like a really well organised cult.  Also, yeah, I like to mix humour when describing dark crap. I think humour is the best defense strategy that protects us from going insane after realising that there is so much BS in this world :D I'm sure Trump won't be the end of the world. Only time will tell - good luck to all of us.

The whole awful situation with the shooting reminds me of recent reactions to John McCain. I've actually seen people on Twitter not only saying the Republicans deserved it, but even hoping they suffer for supporting Trump or, in the case with McCain, simply not siding with the "correct" side of the debate. I saw one particularly nasty person hoping someone shoots McCain next. I don't understand why we're okay with this kind of shit.  I.. almost don't wanna touch the Austin Jones thing. (also what's up with two videos in a row featuring an AJ?)  Part of me feels the guy is a sick fuck who is praying on naive fans who just want to be accepted or seen as popular, but part of me remembers this is exactly the sort of thing we've seen underage (in America) kids do whenever someone they like interacts with them. Even David Bowie had fans admit to sleeping with him when they were underage and never regretted it a day.   HOWEVER, another huge factor here is that there was also no physical interaction with these girls that Austin Jones spoke to. Also, naive or not these two (especially B) had to have understood to some degree what they were getting into. Making and sending videos to someone over the internet is not something you just go "whoops" later on.   I guess I'm just in some sort of weird middle ground. What he did was wrong, and those girls definitely need to understand how stupid what they did was.. but I feel like there's a big gap between physically being in a room and pressuring someone into doing something and talking them into it via online chat. Not to mention the sheer amount of cybering (as it used to be called) that occurred in the 2000s probably makes all this look horribly tame by comparison.  I guess I've just seen enough that's worse to get really worked up over this. Do we have any evidence he didn't delete them as he claimed or otherwise kept them completely private? if he had shared these THEN you'd have a massive shitstorm brewing.

Dude, calling it hebophilia isn't twisting the narrative. There's a massive difference between a pubescent/post-pubescent individual and a prepubescent individual, and how that relates to sex/sexuality. Seriously, don't talk about logic and reason if you're not willing to differentiate these things and speak scientifically and realistically about them. Is it fucked up either way? Absolutely, but I got news for you, it's A LOT more fucked up to be pursuing/fucking/attracted to/etc a prepubescent child, and yeah, it's pedophilia. If someone needs to describe to you why that's more fucked up and wrong than the same attraction or activity with a teenager who has sexually matured, well, I'm not sure what to tell you man. You need to really reflect on this more.   I'm not saying physical/sexual maturity makes what dude did okay, absolutely not. These were still essentially kids, mentally, in the sense that they clearly aren't psychologically mature enough to understand the weight of their actions, or that they are being taken advantage of, and in that sense it's disgusting. I'm merely saying, it's much more disgusting and considered psychologically more significant, to be attracted to children who are not sexually mature at all.   I don't believe in retributive justice, however, so I strongly disagree with 30 years of prison. What he needs is psychological evaluations and severe mental help, and rehabilitation. When it can be proven that he has been rehabilitated, he can be put back in society, but should be forced to at least a year minimum of social/community services of some kind, and have to pay a fine, most of which should go to organizations to help victims of sexual abuse. I think that the casualization of sexuality is largely to blame for scandals like this. We have prominent social media influencers, particularly females, who know that they have an incredibly young following but constantly post highly sexualized photos of themselves and promote it as empowering and a good idea. SuperMaryFace is a prime example of this, and I bring her up because you once featured her on your show. People like her make it seem fun and brave and "empowering" to share risque images of yourself with the internet when it is actually a horrible and dangerous idea, and it is nothing short of irresponsible when you know that most of your followers are children and teens. A leaked nude (even an explicit but clothed photo) can ruin somebody's life, and then you have these people with huge platforms encouraging them to do it.  Society needs to stop making sexuality seem like something that should be casually shared with whoever asks for it. The next generation needs a better influence than that.  There will always be predators, and nothing we do will stop that because they already know that they are doing something wrong, they just don't care. That's why I prefer to focus on the people who claim to be the good guys and who may change their ways if they realize that they are harmful, especially somebody like SuperMaryFace who has intentionally crafted a motherly, role-model relationship with her viewers. But whether somebody intends to be a role model or not, they need to be aware of the impact of their influence.  Mary, Tess Holiday, Kylie Jenner, pretty much every Instagram model and a large number of female YouTubers and streamers... People like that are a huge contributor to the sexualization of young people. And they make it that much easier for a predator to come in and convince them to send a nude.  Sex-selling celebrities are nothing new, but platforms like YouTube have introduced an unprecedented sense of closeness between performer and fan, and that brings greater risk. It's no longer just a shiny celebrity on TV. It's a vlogger who calls you her friend, presents videos as if she is talking to you one on one, whose personal life you see every day on her social media, etc.
And yet,teachers and women who have sexually assaulted boys between the age 5 to 10 only get a year at max........never heard the "feminists" ever talk about this.

I'm glad they got this guy and that he'll be doing a lot of hard time for the absolutely disgusting shit he manipulated these girls into doing, but seriously, this is a two way street here, and I really don't think those girls should just be written off as unsuspecting, innocent angels. These two girls are teenagers, therefore I would have hoped that somewhere along the way they would have stopped and at least thought, "why is he requesting these things?", "this seems really weird and strange to me", or maybe even a "this feels wrong" and most importantly "should I really be doing this?". After all, these girls had to consciously record, "perform" and send these videos to this guy, so they obviously knew what they were doing and they were participating willingly.  If these kids were under the age of 10, I could understand them not really comprehending the gravity of the situation, but in total fairness, I think those two 14 year old girls should get some kind of reprimanding too. I know I'm probably going to get hate for this way of thinking, but honestly unless the victim was completely and totally unaware of what was happening and/or could not in any way/shape/form consent to what was happening to them, both sides of the equation need reprimanding (ban the girls from accessing the Internet at home for a while, take away their phones, do something to bring home the fact that what they contributed to was wrong and that their actions will have consequences). I think the punishment needs to fit the crime. Guilty is not a question. What he did was horrible. But 10 years max, man. 10 years is huge. That's over 10% of your life ripped out of you. Then you stare at it for the full duration. You'll learn what society feels about it right away. You can teach a human anything, including to understand the full effects of their actions and also to love humanity. But over 30% of his life gone? Will rotting really help someone all of a sudden love society? This gives the jury no good option. I wonder if making the punishment the middle ground on what the jury collectively decides and on what the judge decides is a better way to have the system run. Then you can have justice served for just the case at hand, rather than pulling numbers out of their asses so they can cum once the mallet comes down.  Now on to the bigger picture.  You know what? We're using logic to judge emotion. That's fully incorrect. That's not how you think about the pain and suffering of being manipulated, or even the emotions that brought the criminal to do crime. If you haven't noticed, the court system is incapable of judging cases that have to do with the second half of the human mind: emotions. It's an entirely different realm.  There's a term in the software world where the system is created in such a way that its unsustainable and not yet fixed: technical debt. You'd think that a system that deals closely with people would be edited every day until they get it right. These people do not know how to maintain a system. I'm not a conspiracy theorist. I'm just saying. Shit's fucked.

"Estimating Gender Disparities in Federal Criminal Cases"  "University of Michigan Law and Economics Research Paper, No. 12-018"  "This paper assesses gender disparities in federal criminal cases. It finds large gender gaps favoring women throughout the sentence length distribution (averaging over 60%), conditional on arrest offense, criminal history, and other pre-charge observables. Female arrestees are also significantly likelier to avoid charges and convictions entirely, and twice as likely to avoid incarceration if convicted. Prior studies have reported much smaller sentence gaps because they have ignored the role of charging, plea-bargaining, and sentencing fact-finding in producing sentences. Most studies control for endogenous severity measures that result from these earlier discretionary processes and use samples that have been winnowed by them. I avoid these problems by using a linked dataset tracing cases from arrest through sentencing. Using decomposition methods, I show that most sentence disparity arises from decisions at the earlier stages, and use the rich data to investigate causal theories for these gender gaps. "

14-year-olds are extremely easily manipulated. Extremely. When I was 14, I used to go on this site Bebo with friends, it was kind of nerdy, we were roleplaying and having fun with it. But the place was full of pedos. So many 20+-year-old guys. I ended up dating a guy who was 21 at the time, and we dated for 5 months. Within that 5 months, he had asked for nudes. I at first said no...But then he would use the good old lines " if you loved me you would" " don't you trust me?" the conversations would get hostile, aggressive, I feared him dumping me because I thought this guy was the love of my life and when I was 18 I would move to where he lived ( Scotland) and live happily ever after. So... I gave him what he wanted. The relationship was full of mind games, attacking me for the mistakes I made - mistakes every teenager makes in their life. I finally broke up with him, but he logged into my account ( he got my password out of me as well) and was jealous of the guys talking to me so he made a fake account of me, added all of the friends and family from my REAL account ( I had a role play one and real one and he had both). Posted them on my one. My brother saw....I haven o idea if my cousins or other family members saw as they never spoke to me about it. It was horrible. I was only 14. I felt like my life, my reputation was over. I am now almost 24, when I was 21 I fully realised the extent of what happened to me. That I was a victim of a pedophile...because when I look at 14-year-olds, I don't see them in any sexual way, they are too young, they are children in comparison, they are more immature. I remember in my later adolescence I was talking to people younger than me, but then when I turned 18 I felt wrong to talk to them, so I stopped. So when people try to claim that 14-year-olds are old enough to decide who they can date, regardless of age. I strongly disagree, the person you are at 14 is completely different from the person you are when you reach 15, 16, 17, 20, 25 - between these years I saw myself completely change in attitude every year. I changed my mind and opinions a billion times. I was highly emotional, impressionable - AND I WAS CONSIDERED MATURE FOR MY AGE. To date an adult, who already has set beliefs, opinions, they know who they are, they are set in their mind, to date an impressionable kid who is still learning, still trying to understand things in their own way, already influenced my so many adults trying to mold them, I think that is wrong. I think it's about power and control, it turns them on to be able to control and manipulate these girls because they are the easiest to manipulate. I hope what I say and this story helps spread awareness to young girls... Don't let anyone manipulate you. Red flags; if you __(love, trusted) me you would", threats to dump you, any form of threat, " you're different to other girls", any comparison to other girls at all - healthy relationships don't revolve around comparing each other to other people or exes. If you are under the age of consent - any question to ask for nudes is a red flag, especially if they know your age.

Thing is... tower blocks shouldn't EVER burn like this.  They're made of concrete boxes, they're supposed to have fire protection.  That tower, on the other hand, burnt like a candle.  The cladding is not only flammable but actually produced Hydrogen Cyanide gas as it sped up the speed of the fire.  The news is basically that not only will we probably have not have a real fatality count by the end of the year (it's currently at something like 80 people) but testing has found more of these lethal tower blocks around the country... a lot more.  Given that they were at 97 last I heard, and that's after only a few days of testing, I'm guessing the number is going to hit 200 without too much effort. Large scale blazes are always terrible events, what makes this one so bad is that it shouldn't have been possible, could easily have been prevented at many points over a period of years, cost such a large percentage of the residents their lives, and happened in a building where housing was prioritised for poor and disabled families.  The reporting of this fire isn't so loud because of bias against Portugal, it's so loud because every time you think it couldn't get more horrifying they announce some new detail.  And at the bottom of this horrible pit is one or more people who made these decisions, such as picking that particular (and known to be highly toxic) material to cover the building, because they were the cheapest and thus most profitable.

I didn't mean to make it sound like a competition - I've just personally seen a lot of people confused about the true number of casualties of the Grenfell tower. A lot of people have been saying it was 12, I've heard some people say 60s where as the reality is 80s and expected to rise. The reason I think it's significant that people know the true value of deaths is because 1. it's obviously important to remember the true destructiveness of this fire and how many families have been torn apart by this and 2. because it shows how poor the evacuation procedures are in buildings like this. This building, along with thousands of other apartment blocks around the world have a "stay inside" fire policy which contributed to many people not evacuating when they had the chance. Many residents also claimed they didn't wake up to fire alarms going off, they were too quiet - they woke up to the smell of smoke, the heat, the sirens outside, etc. The number of people Grenfell fire claimed shows us extreme safety issues around the world right now. I personally don't think the coverage was so intense because of the recent election - I think it has more to do with how easily this could happen again, the potential past failings of the government and regulators, the huge problem it now poses of rehousing people in an area with very little housing anyway as well as the obvious visual dramatic impact.

Being from the UK I did know about the horrific natural disaster that occurred in Portugal and received information on it from the News as well as via social media. It is tragic and as me and my family visit Portugal pretty much every year, hearing about this definitely hit closer to me than probably most people in the UK. As someone else mentioned the difference is that Grenfell was preventable however loss of life is something that I think should not be compared based on numbers etc. Both should be mourned equally. London is seen as "more important" for reasons unknown and tbh from what I've seen most Americans can't even name more than 3 European countries let alone where they are and the news that comes out of them so I suppose we shouldn't expect for them to be broadcasting news from these smaller less populated (beautiful) countries. I think that Austin should get the 15 year minimum sentence. I don't want anyone to take this the wrong way but I think it's important to acknowledge that this is a MENTAL ILLNESS. A lot of people who you could say, suffer from pedophylic urges are disgusted and ashamed from themselves for having those thoughts. Now the line here is if they ACT on those urges. It's been shown that through extensive therapy, people can overcome these urges and many of them have been found to have been abused in the past. Now once again, I am not in anyway defending Austin or any pedophile who has abused children, I'm just pointing out that there is a difference between having urges and acting on them. People who do have those are sick and it's should be treated with the same level that we treat physical illnesses like cancer, colds, stds, etc. We need to focus on getting people help before they do these terrible things rather than continuing this stigma against mental illnesses which only causes the chance of people acting on them to rise. Now I am 18 and have a 15 year old sister. If I found out that someone was pursing her in an inappropriate way I would automatically get authorities involved but hold what humanity and sympathy I have close to my heart and advocate for rehabilitation rather than imprisonment, whereas if someone put their hands on my sister or manipulated her online like the case we are discussing, then yes, they deserve to be punished. In Austin's case he knew exactly what he was doing, never seeked help to my knowledge and used sick forms of manipulation due to his status. That being said, he IS sick and his fame and success probably doesn't help that, changing the way he views himself and the world and while he is 10 years older than his victims, he is 24 and still relatively young and therefore should receive 15 years rather than 30, giving him the opportunity to get out at the age of 39 and be mandated to seek psychological help, rather than getting out at the age of 54 and possibly reverting back to his old ways.

Average life spans have almost doubled since the dark ages, but again, this is mainly due to infant mortality rates declining significantly. But as for your suggestion that longer lifespans mean "people can wait" - GOOD LUCK WITH THAT. lol Horniness isn't waiting for anything, and biological impulse hasn't changed. Our cultural values have shifted a lot, but biology is still at odds with culture. Did you know that studies among men from around the world show that their "ideal" age of a female is 15? In many regions of the world, it's 14. And this is just the average. What this means is that billions of men around the world think the ideal range is between 13-17. @happy stancetwoable @B.E.T. YESWECAN I'm surprised that anyone would try to play copyright into this even the slightest bit. How could someone think copyright is so important, did you grow up from just watching internet videos? This sounds like a kid trying to imagine a superpower to beat another kid's imagined superpower. Rather than react to every angle on which you get copyright wrong, I'm going to focus on it's irrelevance: copyright is a matter of Civil Law, sexual offenses are a matter of Criminal Law (except I think harassment, I believe that's Civil Law.) Criminal Law eclipses Civil Law; mention copyright in a Criminal Court & I won't be surprised if the judge laughs at you. They are separate systems with different case law, precedent, & standards of evidence. That's why you hear about someone getting found not guilty in Criminal Court, but for the same matter they are ordered to pay $100k in a Civil Law suit. Mere possession is a question that will be asked by this Court, & whether he asked for it is a question that will be asked by this court. Even the worst part of this case, coercion, will effect his sentencing, not be questioned for whether he is guilty. Only asking for it & possessing it will be processed. You 2 seem preoccupied with the broader issue of teen sexuality. This bores me. I only want to bother speaking about this case, yet you bring into this preconceptions of what happened in a case where their dialogue is to the contrary. If they were clothed (at least a bikini or normal underwear) then it wouldn't be illegal. If the minors did this without him requesting nudity, or saving the images, then he would have a strong defense. Or if these were voluntary acts of eager horndogs (even though it would be illegal) then I would be too indifferent, call everyone involved trash, & not bother engaging in YouTube comments of all the lame places, that will dead end eventually. That is not this case, Austin pressured their feelings, they were guilt tripped, they felt twisted into doing acts they didn't seek, & afterward didn't feel any status increase but instead felt used, because they were. They didn't mean anything to him aside from interchangeable jack off material. If they were 40 he'd still be amoral, but the law protects adolescents so now he's a criminal, & anyone who would milk a 14 year old for anything they can be made to do deserves the sex offender registry. I think I should clear up some assumptions that may have been made about me. I would only ever use the word pedophile when the subject is prepubescence. That takes a whole other level of condemnation. I have no shame about finding a teen sexy, I'm just comfortable with the fact that I like 20 somethings the most. Embarrassment to strangers sure, but not shame. Less development less interest, more development more interest, that's not zero attraction, that's inferior appeal. Why would anyone get interested in someone that doesn't look full grown? Normally, the answer is because they are peers. Being at a similar place in life, direct relatability makes up for a short fall of sexiness. Give them 5 years & they will only be hotter & have more understanding of life, which adults need to be able to make up for coming from different places in life. There is nothing healthy about an adult preferring in between features. Fetishizing age like Austin did is freaky; he was directly excited by their age. I can part way relate by imagining being excited about 18, but it's still bizarre the way he puts emphasis on it. Perhaps he's excited by the forbidden, underage, taboo quality of it, it doesn't matter, it's how he used them that is the problem.  I don't care about someone else getting away with foal behavior, I don't care about these laws being more weakly enforced in the 70's, & I don't pretend that middle schoolers don't have the same sexual urges. This is about a case where morality which needs to be enforced to protect those new to these urges from unethical behavior that belittles their value as a person, at a time when they are sensitive to internalizing low self worth.
